awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Designing Expandable and Cost-Effective Server-Centric Interconnects for Data Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
In modern data centers, the performance of data center networks (DCNs) plays a critical role. Currently, DCNs are mainly divided into two categories: switch-centric networks and server-centric networks. In a switch-centric network, switches are responsible for a variety of tasks such as routing and addressing, while servers are only used to send and receive packets in the network. In a server-centric network, the computational intensive tasks like routing are put on the servers, which act not only as end hosts, but also as relay nodes for each other. A significant advantage of server-centric networks is that network hardware cost can be drastically reduced, as inexpensive commodity switches are sufficient given that most complex network tasks have been shifted to servers where computation resources are abundant. Moreover, since servers are much more programmable than switches, server-centric networks can accelerate the process of network innovation. Motivated by the importance and opportunities of deploying server-centric networks in DCNs, this research systematically investigates the fundamental and challenging issues towards building cost-efficient server-centric DCNs with guaranteed performance.


The objective of this research is to design novel, extendable and cost-effective server-centric interconnects and associated routing algorithms for data centers. This research explores the unique novel features and techniques in data centers to build cost-efficient interconnects with dual-port servers or any fixed number of NIC ports. More specifically, the research focuses on following closely coupled issues: (1) construct cost-efficient DCN interconnects using commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) switches and dual-port servers that are available in current markets; (2) efficient routing algorithms for unicast, broadcast and multicast that can sufficiently take advantage of the novel interconnects; (3) employ network virtualization technology to offer a more flexible solution to both industry and academic research; (4) construct cost-efficient DCN interconnects using servers with any fixed number of NIC ports that meet the trend of future servers; (5) conduct a comprehensive performance evaluation through extensive simulations and implementation of proposed schemes in a realistic network prototype. The proposed research combines theoretical analysis, algorithm design, network optimization, simulation and prototyping techniques to provide a comprehensive working solution that enables high performance next generation DCNs. This research hopes to impact fundamental design principles of server-centric DCNs. The outcome of this research has the potential to boost the performance of DCNs while keeping the cost low, and facilitate numerous cloud computing applications currently hosted in data centers. A project goal is to train graduate students and promote the participation of female engineering students. The important findings of this project are to be disseminated to the research community by way of conferences, journals and web site access.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past several decades, the phenomenal development of data centers has made them the core infrastructure of almost all daily online services. One key to a successful data center is a well-designed  network that connects all servers in a highly efficient and cost-effective way. The goal of this project is to pave the way towards more agile, reliable, and cost-efficient data center networks. We mainly work on three interrelated tracks, i.e., designing a server-centric network architecture overcoming drawbacks of the state of the art, developing schemes leading to more efficient and reliable network function virtualization, bridging edge and cloud computing for the trending edge-cloud continuum with network virtualization technologies.

Track 1: Among data center network topologies, server-centric topologies are well-known for their low hardware cost and innovation potentials. Nevertheless, insufficient scalability and reliability of existing server-centric networks limit their further development and popularity. In this project, we have made a fundamental impact in the research field of server-centric networks by making up for its shortcomings without losing its advantages.

Given that existing server-centric topologies are either not expandable or demanding prohibitive expansion cost, we have designed a novel server-centric architecture with new network topologies, addressing schemes, and routing algorithms. Our architecture enables a data center network to easily accommodate a large number of servers while keeping a very small network diameter. The diameter has a linear increase to the order of the network compared to the exponential increase in the state of the art. This improvement means we can easily expand the network by adding inexpensive commodity servers and switches with little alteration of the existing structure.

Moreover, different from existing server-centric network structures which do not adapt to redundancy configurations and fail to meet today's stringent high availability requirements, our architecture is designed to provide graceful performance degradation in case of component failures. It can be easily configured into redundancy and failover schemes with high reliability. Moreover, both theoretical analysis and experimental results show that our designs preserve similar or even achieve better on metrics such as energy efficiency, bandwidth capacity, and latency compared to existing work. Thus, our work makes it much easier to keep up with the fast-growing scales of data centers and brings promising prospects for performance upgrading and reliability guarantee.

Track 2: With well-designed network architectures, we further focused on employing network function virtualization technologies to offer congestion-free, reliable, and environment friendly data center networks.

With virtual network functions (VNFs), network services in data centers are realized by interconnected VNFs called service function chains (SFC) with new flexibility. However, flexible SFC deployment may lead to network congestion without proper service placement and flow routing schemes. Therefore, we have proposed an online SFC placement and flow routing scheme that delivers a thoughtful tradeoff between cost reduction and congestion control. The theoretically guaranteed algorithms can achieve close-to-optimal solutions even with violent fluctuations of workload and traffic flows.

According to related literature, the complex virtual architectures of SFCs make them more vulnerable to failures. Besides our server-centric architecture guaranteeing hardware-level reliability, we have further proposed joint SFC backup and rerouting strategies at the software level that provide sufficient redundancy without aggravating network congestion. In addition, an online green VNF backup strategy was proposed to leverage renewable energy for cost-efficient VNF backups.

While the majority of the state of the art aims at amplifying the benefits of VNFs, our work provides thoughtful tradeoffs between positive and negative impacts of VNFs to the data center. Thus, we help make up for the missing but crucial step towards efficient network function virtualization in data centers.

Track 3: It is worth noting that the coexistence and cooperation of cloud computing and edge computing is becoming a trend for future computing configuration, because edge computing can provide high Quality of Experience (QoE) services within the users' proximity while cloud computing will always have higher cost-effectiveness due to the law of large numbers. Therefore, we also studied how to leverage network function virtualization technologies to facilitate the edge-cloud continuum in this project.

We have proposed SFC placement and resource management strategies for full utilization of edge resources and system latency minimization in edge-cloud networks. We have also designed a reliability-aware adaptive SFC backup scheme in edge-cloud environments which self-adaptively adjusts SFC backups over edge servers and data centers for the sweet spot between low cost and high reliability. Moreover, we have designed a scheme that deploys memory-hungry machine learning inferences over the edge and cloud servers for latency minimization with the help of non-volatile memory.

Both theoretical conclusions and small-scale real-world prototypes showed that our work, concerning providing reliable and cost-effective virtual networks in heterogenous edge-cloud environments, is one important step towards bridging the gap between the edge and the cloud and achieving the best performance combining the advantages of both sides.
